questions.question_text: A cybersecurity analyst wants to use ICMP ECHO_REQUEST on a machine while using Nmap. Which of the following is the correct command to accomplish this?

discussion.content: "Additionally, the analyst has noticed that corporate data is being stored at this new location" -> This looks like data exfiltration, since: "the IP is on different subnet" and "there is no record of this IP address"
The IP is on a totally different network..

Maybe if the Security Analyst has worked at the company a long time then this wouldn't be change management. If Data Exfiltration is the answer then the question is missing a couple of key points that would've directed you in this direction.

comments.content: There isnt any suggestion of change, they only note that data is now being held there. Therefore C :)

Upper management are often the target of phishing mails. If a few of them got them and ran some malicious attachments, it's very likely that those accounts/hosts would be compromised and therefor seen exfiltrating data.
I think so also. This is very unlikely to be data exfiltration since the user's storing data on the unknown IP address are from the upper management team.

discussion.content: I feel like this is unauthorized change

questions.question_text:
In reviewing firewall logs, a security analyst has discovered the following IP address, which several employees are using frequently:
152.100.57.18
The organization's servers use IP addresses in the 192.168.0.1/24 CIDR. Additionally, the analyst has noticed that corporate data is being stored at this new location. A few of these employees are on the management and executive management teams. The analyst has also discovered that there is no record of this IP address or service in reviewing the known locations of managing system assets. Which of the following is occurring in this scenario?

discussion.content: the condition for this vulnerability is to have running mod_cgid ("Due to a flaw found in mod_cgid, a server using mod_cgid to host CGI scripts could be vulnerable to a DoS attack"), which those servers aren't ("the server hosts standard CGI scripts for the wiki sites, DOES NOT HAVE mod_cgid installed, is running Apache 2.2.22, and is not behind a WAF")
Why is B correct?

questions.question_text:
A vulnerability scan returned the following results for a web server that hosts multiple wiki sites:
Apache-HTTPD-cve-2014-023: Apache HTTPD: mod_cgid denial of service CVE-2014-0231
Due to a flaw found in mod_cgid, a server using mod_cgid to host CGI scripts could be vulnerable to a DoS attack caused by a remote attacker who is exploiting a weakness in non-standard input, causing processes to hang indefinitely.
//IMG//

The security analyst has confirmed the server hosts standard CGI scripts for the wiki sites, does not have mod_cgid installed, is running Apache 2.2.22, and is not behind a WAF. The server is located in the DMZ, and the purpose of the server is to allow customers to add entries into a publicly accessible database.
Which of the following would be the MOST efficient way to address this finding?

choices.B: Document the finding as a false positive.
choices.A: Place the server behind a WAF to prevent DoS attacks from occurring.
choices.C: Upgrade to the newest version of Apache.
choices.D: Disable the HTTP service and use only HTTPS to access the server.

discussion.content: What does C tell you? Booting from both disks is certainly changing attributes, reg values etc. so the hash will not be the same anymore. Forensics need to make an exact copy of the disk and verify this by hashing. B & D

i'm having second thoughts here.. 
We know that best practices are to "Use write blocker" and "compare hash".
But.. once you have done the copy of the image.. how to ensure that is the same? Maybe is B&C

How does a write blocker allow you to ensure that the image is the same as the original disk? Whereas, you boot them both up and compare their values or check the hash values to ensure they are the same... Just saying...
B and D
B and D is the right answer
B & D. I don't know who marked that C, but I would not want to have that person in my forensics team... .
B and D.
Write blocker should be one of the answers

comments.content: agree, it should be B & D

choices.C: Boot up the image and the original systems to compare.
choices.D: Connect a write blocker to the imaging device.
choices.A: Validate the folder and file directory listings on both.
choices.E: Copy the data to a disk of the same size and manufacturer.
choices.B: Check the hash value between the image and the original.

questions.question_text: A security administrator uses FTK to take an image of a hard drive that is under investigation. Which of the following processes are used to ensure the image is the same as the original disk? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Firewall can only see traffic with source=proxy IP based on the topology. All hosts will connect to proxy then proxy will connect to Internet. 
Firewall can never see IP 192.168.1.6 as a source. 
So it should be DENY TCP 192.168.1.10 ANY 2.63.25.201 80
ok i get bqtest2.ru is reoccurring to avoid this happening you deny the site with the appropriate parameters.
Remember 192.168.1.6 is malware.com. so i would go for deny tcp 192.168.1.6 any 2.63.25.201.80 .80
Where are these answers even coming from? It doesn't make sense to deny the workstation's SIP when the firewall logs only receives the web proxy server's SIP.
This question was on the exam (october-2020)

comments.content: please what is the correct answer at the end? I'm confused with all these explanations

DENY - TCP - 192.168.1.6 - ANY - 2.63.25.201 - 80 imho is the correct answer. Like Ivnkai noted, blocking the proxy IP address, will not allow any traffic behind the proxy to go through, but specifying the specific IP address which was identified as the source of the beaconing from the web output, will surely deny all TCP traffic from host 192.168.1.6 to the specific destination 2.63.25.201 on port 80(HTTP)

No. You are not blocking all traffic being sourced from 192.168.1.10. 
You are just blocking traffic with sourceIP=192.168.1.10 AND destIP=2.63.25.201 AND destPort=80.

No. It will not stop all traffic. 
It will just stop traffic from any endpoint -> 2.63.25.201 (bq2test.ru) on port 80. Since the port is changing on source-IP, we can't filter by it. And since the IP address is being translated, we can't be more granular.

NAT translation is happening on Web-proxy.
Firewall just sees all incoming packets with sourceIP=192.168.1.10
If you check on firewall logs, you can see that all permits/deny have SourceIP=192.168.1.10

discussion.content: guys ,if you block 1.10 it will stop traffic from all workstations, not just 1.6 . Do we want it , I guess no. So I will stick with the answer 1.6 ---block :80

Look guys, the acl rule we have to modify is for the firewall not the proxy server acl rule set. The web logs source IP has already show the beaconing started from the host 192.168.1.6. As a result the firewall server is not going to stop the source traffic from 192.168.1.6 which you indicate to deny in 192.168.1.10. Because simply put, the packet header will indicate the source ip address is 192.168.1.6 even as it passes through the proxy server of 192.168.1.10, its not going to change the source ip address. only mac addresses changes at each hop, but never source and destination ip addresses.
testing

The solution is: DENY - TCP - 192.168.1.6 - ANY - 2.63.25.201 - 80

Here's my reasoning: We're looking for beacon traffic that isn't blocked. Beacon traffic - by definition - would be something reoccurring every X amount of time. An easy way to recognize it is by looking for activity between two of the same hosts (internal to external) to the same destination port.

comments.content:
Woops, nope. It should indeed be the source of the proxy device. I completely missed that proxy lol. This is the correct answer:
DENY - TCP - 192.168.1.10 - ANY - 2.63.25.201 - 80
I agree because this is the only IP that the firewall will see. It will not see the machine IP after it goes through the proxy as shown in the firewall logs.

discussion.content: I saw this question on the exam.
any clarification on this, because the proxy ip is 192.168.1.10, therefore shouldn't it be blocked there, not at the host IP of 192.168.1.6?
This solution is incorrect. The rule needs to have a source port of the proxy, since that is what the firewall sees as source IP.

comments.content: Source IP of the proxy server I mean.... not port...
Wouldn't the correct answer be, DENY | TCP | 192.168.1.6 | 7999 | 67.8.9.224 | 8080?
What would you say the solution is?
No, because the malicious external IP is connecting via different ports in the logs.
